thread.title: Ames Jaycees helps celebrate 100 years of JCI movement
thread.title_full: Ames Jaycees helps celebrate 100 years of JCI movement

title: Ames Jaycees helps celebrate 100 years of JCI movement
text:
Ames Jaycees helps celebrate 100 years of JCI movement By Julie Ferrell, Staff Writer jferrell@amestrib.com 
Since the Junior Chamber International (JCI) Movement began 100 years ago, the Ames branch of the nonprofit organization has started several events across town, and the group plans to celebrate the 100th anniversary with a presentation this afternoon. 
The movement officially began Oct. 13, 1915, when Henry Giessenbier, of St. Louis, Mo., created the membership-based nonprofit for citizens ages 18 to 40 dedicated to positive change in their communities. 
Since then, more than 5,000 branches with millions of members have formed across 100 countries and 84 years ago, an Ames branch of the “Jaycees” was born. 
“(Giessenbier) really felt like young people needed a way to connect with one another and make an impact in their community,” said Breanna Wetzler, a past president for the Ames Jaycees. “So the overarching point of the Jaycees is to get young people engaged with one another and make an impact in their community for the better.” 
The event this afternoon will feature speaker Jennifer Gracey, of Clive, who is both a member and a co-chair for the anniversary celebrations around the world, and will screen a short JCI documentary. But the overall celebration is meant to highlight the Ames chapter’s work and celebrate the multiple partnerships the organization works with in the community. 
Wetzler, who has been involved with the Ames Jaycees since 2010, said some of the largest projects the group has done are the Holiday Food Baskets, which provide meals to low-income families during the holiday season, and the Ames on the Half Shell summer concert series. 
Wetzler said the events allow the Jaycees to collaborate with several other local organizations, like Mid-Iowa Community Action (MICA) or with local hotels for one of the group’s newest projects, the New Year’s Eve Bash. 
The partnerships, along with the positive change she has seen the group create, are some of the reasons Wetzler continues to be a part of the Ames branch. 
“It helped me really feel connected to the community and I know if something happens, should I not stay in Ames and move to another community, the first thing I’ll do is look for a surrounding Jaycee chapter,” she said. “Everyone has their own pet project and one you find that, it’s just the most amazing feeling. The Jaycees can be anything to anybody, it’s whatever you want to put in, and the Jaycees can help you do it.” 

Where: Farwell T. Brown Auditorium, Ames Public Library, 515 Douglas Ave. 
When: 2 to 4 p.m. today 
Cost: Free Rules for posting comments
